1.  Find $\frac{d}{dx}9(x + x^2)$.
2.  $f(x, y) = 3x^2y$. Find $\nabla f(x, y)$.
3.  $f(x, y) = 3x^2y, g(x, y) = 2x + y^8$.
    a. Find the Jacobian containing $\nabla f(x, y)$ and $\nabla g(x, y)$ in numerator layout.
    b. Find the Jacobian containing $\nabla f(x, y)$ and $\nabla g(x, y)$ in denominator layout.
4.  Let $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{x}}) = f_i(x_i)$. Show that $\frac{\partial \vec{\rm{y}}}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = I$
5.  $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{w}}) \bigcirc \vec{\rm{g}}(\vec{\rm{x}}) = f_i(w_i) \bigcirc g_i(x_i)$. Prove the following identities.
    a. If $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{w}}) \oplus \vec{\rm{g}}(\vec{\rm{x}})$
        i. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \oplus \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{w}}} = I$.
        ii. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \oplus \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = I$.
    b. If $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{w}}) \ominus \vec{\rm{g}}(\vec{\rm{x}})$
        i. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \ominus \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{w}}} = I$.
        ii. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \ominus \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = -I$.
    c. If $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{w}}) \otimes \vec{\rm{g}}(\vec{\rm{x}})$
        i. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \otimes \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{w}}} = \text{diag}(\vec{\rm{x}})$.
        ii. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \otimes \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = \text{diag}(\vec{\rm{w}})$.
    d. If $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{w}}) \oslash \vec{\rm{g}}(\vec{\rm{x}})$
        i. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \oslash \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{w}}} = \text{diag}\left(\cdots \frac{1}{x_i} \cdots \right)$.
        ii. show that $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{w}} \oslash \vec{\rm{x}})}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = \text{diag}\left(\cdots \frac{-w_i}{x^2_i} \cdots \right)$.
6. $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{x}}) \bigcirc \vec{\rm{g}}(z) = \vec{\rm{x}} \bigcirc \vec{1}z$. Prove the following identities (in both general form//without expansion and detailed form//with expansion).
    a. $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{x}} \oplus z)}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}}  = I$
    b. $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{x}} \oplus z)}{\partial z}  = \vec{1}$
    c. $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{x}} \otimes z)}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}}  = Iz$
    d. $\frac{\partial (\vec{\rm{x}} \otimes z)}{\partial z}  = \vec{\rm{x}}$
7. $y = \text{sum}\left(\vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{x}})\right) = \sum^n_{i=1}f_i(\vec{\rm{x}})$, where $f_i(\vec{\rm{x}}) â‰  x_i$. Solve for $\frac{\partial y}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}}$.
8. $y = \text{sum}(\vec{\rm{x}})$. Show that $\nabla y = \vec{1}^T$
9. $y = \text{sum}(\vec{\rm{x}}z)$.
    a. Show that $\frac{\partial y}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = \vec{1}^Tz$
    b. Show that $\frac{\partial y}{\partial z} = \text{sum}(\vec{\rm{x}})$
10. Find $\frac{d}{dx} \sin(x^2)$
11. $y = \ln(\sin^2(x^3))$. Find $\frac{dy}{dx}$.
12. $y = f(x) = x + x^2$. Solve for $\frac{dy}{dx}$ using total derivatives.
13. Show that $\frac{\partial f(x, u_1, \dots, u_n)}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x} + \sum^n_{i=1}\frac{\partial f}{\partial u_i}\frac{\partial u_i}{\partial x}$
    a. Further simplify $\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} + \sum^n_{i=1}\frac{\partial f}{\partial u_i}\frac{\partial u_i}{\partial x}$ to $\sum^{n+1}_{i=1}\frac{\partial f}{\partial u_i}\frac{\partial u_i}{\partial x}$.
14. $f(x) = \sin(x+x^2)$. Solve for \frac{df(x)}{dx}.
15. $y = x \times x^2$. Solve for $\frac{dy}{dx}$ using total derivatives.
16. $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(\vec{\rm{g}}(x))$. Show that $\frac{\partial\vec{\rm{y}}}{\partial x} = \frac{\partial \vec{\rm{f}}}{\partial \vec{\rm{g}}} \cdot \frac{\partial \vec{\rm{g}}}{\partial x}$.
17. $\vec{\rm{y}} = \vec{\rm{f}}(x) = \begin{bmatrix} y_1(x) \\ y_2(x) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} f_1(x) \\ f_2(x) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \ln(x^2) \\ \sin(3x) \end{bmatrix}$. Find $\frac{d\vec{\rm{y}}}{dx}$ <!-- by using an intermediate vector $\vec{\rm{g}}(x)$ -->.
18. $\vec{\rm{f}}\left(\vec{\rm{g}}(\vec{\rm{x}})\right)$, where $f_i(\vec{\rm{x}}) = g_i(\vec{\rm{x}})=x_i$.
    a. Show that $\frac{\partial \vec{\rm{f}}}{\partial \vec{\rm{g}}} = \text{diag}\left(\frac{\partial f_i}{\partial g_i}\right)$
    b. Show that $\frac{\partial \vec{\rm{g}}}{\partial \vec{\rm{x}}} = \text{diag}\left(\frac{\partial g_i}{\partial x_i}\right)$
